frame.name: FR_Expectation
frame.definition:
<def-root>Words in this frame have to do with a <fen>Cognizer</fen> believing that some <fen>Phenomenon</fen> will take place in the future. Some words in the frame (e.g. FR:<ment>anticiper.v</ment>) indicate that the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is asserted also to be true, while others do not.
<ex><fex name="Cog">Michael</fex> <t>expected</t> <fex name="Phen">Abby</fex> <fex name="Phen">to demand examples</fex>.</ex> <ex><fex name="Evidence">From the look on her face</fex> <fex name="Cog">Michael</fex> <t>expected</t> <fex name="Phen">that she would say she got the job</fex>.</ex>
<ex></ex>
<asf>Relation to fndata-1.5</asf> : Add of the <fen>Time_of_Eventuality</fen> FE, as it can be subcategorized by the LUs of this frame.
</def-root>

FE.name: Cognizer
FE.definition: <def-root>This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name="Cognizer">Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series. </def-root>

FE.name: Phenomenon
FE.definition: <def-root>This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations): <ex>Pat <t>expects</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.</ex> <ex>Pat <t>expects</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">a big win</fex>.</ex> <ex>Pat <t>expects</t> <fex name="Phenomenon">the Yankees</fex> <fex name="Phenomenon">to win the World Series</fex>.</ex> General Grammatical Observations: Many of the verbs in this frame allow Raising: Pat <t>expects</t> it to rain. In the example above, the word <ment>it</ment> is grammatically the Object of the target verb <ment>expect</ment>, but it does not express an FE. Rather, it is merely construed as the External Argument of the verb <ment>rain</ment>, which heads the VP Complement of the target. In this situation, both the raised consituent <ment>it</ment> and the VP Complement are marked with the <fex name="Phen">Phenomenon</fex> FE, but are marked as separate constituents. That is because the Object can be passivized and therefore not appear adjacent to the VP Complement: It is <t>expected</t> to rain. </def-root>

FE.name: Time_of_Eventuality
FE.definition: <def-root>The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> expects the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> to occur. <ex>She <t>predicted</t> the outcry for <fex name="tim">1992</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Evidence
FE.definition: <def-root>Words in this frame may occur with a PP headed by <ment>from</ment> which expresses the Evidence on which knowledge or belief is based: I have <t>learned</t> <fex name="Evidence">from experience</fex> that poison oak can be painful. </def-root>

FE.name: Topic
FE.definition:
<def-root>An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
<ex><t>Predictions</t> <fex name="Topic">about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.</ex></def-root>

frameRelation.type: Relation to FN1.5: Is Close to
